title: Bernard Richard
text:
Bernard Richard (born April 11, 1951) is a <a href="Canadians">Canadian</a> <a href="social%20worker">social worker</a>, <a href="lawyer">lawyer</a>, and <a href="politician">politician</a> in the <a href="New%20Brunswick">Province of New Brunswick</a>.
Early life and education.
Raised and educated in <a href="Cap-Pel%C3%A9%2C%20New%20Brunswick">Cap-Pelé, New Brunswick</a>, Richard earned a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> degree from the <a href="University%20of%20Moncton">University of Moncton</a> and a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Laws">Bachelor of Laws</a> degree from the <a href="University%20of%20New%20Brunswick">University of New Brunswick</a>.
Political career.
He first entered politics as a young man, running unsuccessfully in <a href="Shediac">Shediac</a> for the <a href="Legislative%20Assembly%20of%20New%20Brunswick">Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick</a> as a <a href="Parti%20acadien">Parti Acadien</a> candidate in the <a href="1974%20New%20Brunswick%20general%20election">1974 election</a>. He became involved in municipal politics in the <a href="village">village</a> of Cap-Pélé. His second entry into provincial politics was in the <a href="1991%20New%20Brunswick%20general%20election">1991 election</a>, this time as a <a href="New%20Brunswick%20Liberal%20Association">Liberal</a>. He won. He was re-elected in <a href="1995%20New%20Brunswick%20general%20election">1995</a>, <a href="1999%20New%20Brunswick%20general%20election">1999</a> and <a href="2003%20New%20Brunswick%20general%20election">2003</a>.
He was named to <a href="Executive%20Council%20of%20New%20Brunswick">cabinet</a> in 1995 and left in 1998 to contest the leadership of the Liberal Party. He was unsuccessful in his leadership bid and was returned to the cabinet position by <a href="Camille%20Th%C3%A9riault">Camille Thériault</a> who was the victor in the contest. Richard managed to be re-election by the largest margin of any candidate in the 1999 election, despite the fact that his party suffering a massive defeat.
When Thériault resigned as leader in 2001, Richard briefly considered another run but instead became <a href="Interim%20leader%20%28Canada%29">interim leader</a>. When <a href="Shawn%20Graham">Shawn Graham</a> became leader in 2002, Richard was made <a href="House%20Leader">House Leader</a> and finance critic, two key roles in the opposition. Richard maintained these roles after the 2003 election.
The <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20New%20Brunswick">Progressive Conservative</a> government of <a href="Bernard%20Lord">Bernard Lord</a> had won a bare majority in 2003, winning 28 of 55 seats and were anxious to strengthen their position. After first attempting to convince a Liberal to sit as <a href="speaker%20%28politics%29">speaker</a> and then offering cabinet positions and other appointments to several Liberals, Richard accepted the post of provincial <a href="ombudsman">ombudsman</a>, thus resigning his seat and increasing the <a href="Tory">Tory</a> majority to 28/54 for the ensuing year before a <a href="by-election">by-election</a> was held.
On November 6, 2007, New Brunswick news outlets reported that the Progressive Conservatives were encouraging Richard to leave his post as ombudsman and return to politics <a href="2008%20Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20New%20Brunswick%20leadership%20election">as leader</a> of their party.
